title: Time Series Analysis
text:
A time series is any sequence of measurements taken at regular, equally spaced intervals—seconds, minutes, hours, days, months, quarters, or years. Common examples include weather (daily temperature or rainfall), financial markets (daily stock prices or returns), industry indicators (monthly production or sales), electricity demand, traffic counts, and hospital admissions. In time-series analysis we study how these values evolve: their level, trend, seasonal or calendar patterns (e.g., weekdays vs. weekends, holiday effects), cycles, and anomalies. Typical goals are to describe behavior clearly, forecast future values, and quantify the impact of events or policies.
Because observations are ordered in time, nearby points tend to be correlated (autocorrelation). This violates the independent-and-identically-distributed assumption behind many standard statistical methods, so naïve cross-sectional tools often mislead. Time-series work must explicitly handle dependence, trend, and seasonality—for example by differencing, seasonal adjustment, and models that use lagged values and errors (e.g., ARIMA/SARIMA, ARIMAX/SARIMAX with external drivers, VAR for multiple series, state-space/ETS, or GARCH when volatility changes over time). Analysts also watch for structural breaks (e.g., policy shifts, COVID), outliers, and missing periods, and they evaluate models with time-aware validation (rolling or blocked splits) rather than random shuffles.

title: Time Series Analysis
text:
A time series is any sequence of measurements taken at regular, equally spaced intervals—seconds, minutes, hours, days, months, quarters, or years. Common examples include weather (daily temperature or rainfall), financial markets (daily stock prices or returns), industry indicators (monthly production or sales), electricity demand, traffic counts, and hospital admissions. In time-series analysis we study how these values evolve: their level, trend, seasonal or calendar patterns (e.g., weekdays vs. weekends, holiday effects), cycles, and anomalies. Typical goals are to describe behavior clearly, forecast future values, and quantify the impact of events or policies.
Because observations are ordered in time, nearby points tend to be correlated (autocorrelation). This violates the independent-and-identically-distributed assumption behind many standard statistical methods, so naïve cross-sectional tools often mislead. Time-series work must explicitly handle dependence, trend, and seasonality—for example by differencing, seasonal adjustment, and models that use lagged values and errors (e.g., ARIMA/SARIMA, ARIMAX/SARIMAX with external drivers, VAR for multiple series, state-space/ETS, or GARCH when volatility changes over time). Analysts also watch for structural breaks (e.g., policy shifts, COVID), outliers, and missing periods, and they evaluate models with time-aware validation (rolling or blocked splits) rather than random shuffles.

title: About Me
text:
Hi! Glad to meet you here:)
I’m Tongrui（Neil) Zhang, currently a graduate student in Georgetown University DSAN program learning about time series. I love looking into data and learning about how it can be used to solve or explain real-world problems.
Here will be my portfolio of this course!

title: Introduction
text:
“Eggs at $4? Gas over $5? Rent jumped—again.”
On a chilly morning in early 2023, a grocery receipt went viral: the total looked ordinary, but line items told a story—eggs doubled from a year earlier, milk and bread were up, and a short drive across town now cost noticeably more. That receipt captured what many households felt: inflation isn’t abstract—it shows up in carts, bills, and budgets.
This project asks a simple question with complex answers: How does inflation transmit into the everyday cost of living in the United States—across food, housing, utilities, transportation, and beyond—over time?

title: Introduction
text:
Angles & Candidate Time-Series Sources

1) Food Costs (at home vs away from home)
What to study: Size/timing of pass-through; category heterogeneity; energy & wage channels.
Sources: - BLS CPI: Food at home, Food away from home (monthly) - USDA ERS: Food Price Outlook (monthly narrative & tables) - EIA retail fuel & energy prices (weekly/monthly) - BLS CES: industry hourly earnings (monthly)


2) Shelter Costs (rent, OER, market rents)
What to study: CPI shelter’s stickiness; market rent → CPI lags; mortgage rate environment.
Sources: - BLS CPI: Shelter, Rent of primary residence, Owners’ equivalent rent - Zillow/Apartment List Rent Index (monthly) | Apartment List - Freddie Mac PMMS mortgage rates (weekly) - S&P/Case-Shiller Home Price (monthly)


3) Utilities & Home Energy (electricity, gas, water/sewer/trash)
What to study: Seasonal structure; energy shocks; weather load (HDD/CDD).
Sources: - BLS CPI: Electricity, Utility (piped) gas service, Water/sewer/trash - EIA: retail electricity & natural gas prices/consumption - NOAA: HDD/CDD and temperature time series


4) Transportation & Fuel (gasoline, transit, auto services)
What to study: Oil → gasoline pass-through; asymmetry (rocket-feather); service costs.
Sources: - BLS CPI: Gasoline, Transportation services (e.g., insurance, maintenance) - EIA: WTI/Brent, retail gasoline (weekly) - BLS PPI for upstream costs


5) Household Services (childcare, health out-of-pocket, education, internet/phone)
What to study: Price stickiness; trend vs cyclical; income sensitivity.
Sources: - BLS CPI detailed services (monthly) - FRED health/education price indexes


6) Regional & Demographic Heterogeneity
What to study: Metro/regional CPI; urban vs non-urban; distributional burden.
Sources: - BLS regional CPI & selected metro indexes - BEA regional price parity (annual with trend context) - CPS micro indicators (for demographic overlays)


7) Expectations & Sentiment
What to study: Do inflation expectations predict category moves?
Sources: - NY Fed Survey of Consumer Expectations (monthly) - University of Michigan Surveys of Consumers - Market-based inflation compensation (breakevens via FRED)


8) Supply Chains & Commodities
What to study: Import prices, shipping costs, ag/industrial commodities → retail.
Sources: - BLS Import/Export Price Indexes - FAO Food Price Index - Freight indices (e.g., Drewry/FBX—if accessible)


9) Policy Episodes & Regime Shifts (e.g., COVID-19, tightening cycles)
What to study: Before/after analyses, breaks, and time-varying pass-through.
Sources: - Federal Reserve monetary policy timeline - Fiscal policy events (Treasury/Congressional sources) - CPI category histories (BLS)


10) Forecasts & Scenarios (12–24 months)
What to study: Conditional paths: if core inflation/energy follows a path, where do costs go?
Sources: - Consensus forecasts (e.g., Survey of Professional Forecasters) - EIA Short-Term Energy Outlook - Internal model outputs (produced later)


11) Budget Burden & Distribution (who bears the pain)
What to study: Expenditure shares and effective inflation by group.
Sources: - BLS Consumer Expenditure Survey (annual/quarterly detail) - CPI weights and category shares


12) Nowcasting & High-Frequency Signals (optional)
What to study: Weekly/daily signals that anticipate monthly CPI subcomponents.
Sources: - EIA weekly fuel - Card-type or scanner data if accessible - Web-scraped price indicators (methodology-dependent)

title: Introduction
section: Food prices: pass-through, lags, and inputs
text:
Food prices: pass-through, lags, and inputs
Retail food inflation typically shows incomplete and lagged pass-through from upstream shocks; energy and labor costs often matter more than raw farm commodities for shelf prices. USDA’s Food Price Outlook documents pandemic-era supply disruptions, disease shocks (e.g., HPAI for eggs), and forecasting updates, providing granular monthly CPI/PPI series and narrative event windows that motivate distributed-lag modeling by category. Recent Federal Reserve research quantifies U.S. farm-to-retail pass-through magnitudes and delays, offering priors for our ARDL/local projection specifications and a benchmark for cross-category heterogeneity. We will combine CPI food subindexes with energy and wage covariates and evaluate pre/post-COVID stability. :contentReferenceoaicite:0

title: Introduction
section: Shelter: stickiness and measured lags between market rents and CPI
text:
Shelter: stickiness and measured lags between market rents and CPI
A central result is that CPI shelter responds with multi-month lags to movements in market rents due to lease terms, renewal smoothing, and BLS’s six-month change design. Ball (2025) formalizes mechanisms that reconcile diverging paths of private rent indices and CPI shelter during 2022–2024; this directly motivates our empirical design treating market rents as leading indicators and testing lag lengths/persistence. Policy briefs and practitioner notes further stress the persistence of shelter inflation relative to private measures, reinforcing our plan for before/after COVID and high-inflation-regime analyses. :contentReferenceoaicite:1

title: Introduction
text:
Transportation fuels: asymmetric “rockets and feathers”
The oil-to-gasoline pass-through literature documents asymmetry—pump prices rise faster than they fall (“rockets and feathers”). U.S. studies report regional variation and nonlinearity, implying state-dependent responses we should address with threshold/interaction terms or quantile-based local projections. We will apply asymmetric pass-through diagnostics to gasoline CPI, embedding crude or wholesale gasoline as drivers alongside controls for taxes and seasonality. :contentReferenceoaicite:2

title: Introduction
section: Utilities and home energy: weather, seasonality, and energy channels
text:
Utilities and home energy: weather, seasonality, and energy channels
Household electricity and piped gas costs are strongly seasonal and weather-sensitive; heating/cooling degree days (HDD/CDD) are standard predictors of load and bills. Federal technical documentation and energy outlook analyses define HDD/CDD construction and their use in modeling energy demand. We will incorporate HDD/CDD into additive/multiplicative seasonal decompositions (STL or X-11 where relevant) and into monthly ARDLs for electricity and gas service CPI, testing for interactions with fuel prices. :contentReferenceoaicite:3

title: Introduction
section: Supply chains, COVID-era regimes, and policy episodes
text:
Supply chains, COVID-era regimes, and policy episodes
Pandemic-era inflation featured a regime shift: in 2021 global supply chain shocks dominated, while in 2022 traditional demand/supply forces reasserted importance; monetary policy also appears more effective after supply-chain shocks. We will therefore run structural-break tests, estimate regime-dependent pass-through, and annotate event windows (e.g., tightening cycles) across categories. This framework links our before/after COVID comparisons to causal narratives about bottlenecks, re-opening, and policy response. :contentReferenceoaicite:4

title: Introduction
section: Trade, import prices, and the dollar
text:
Trade, import prices, and the dollar
Global work shows the U.S. dollar plays a dominant role in world trade pricing; a 1% dollar appreciation predicts a 0.6–0.8% decline in global trade volumes within a year, with high pass-through into import prices. Classic and subsequent papers on currency of invoicing explain low exchange-rate pass-through to U.S. consumer prices when imports are dollar-priced, while tariff pass-through at the border/store differs and can be high for targeted goods. For our angles, we treat dollar moves and import/retail price links as external drivers for traded goods categories (e.g., gasoline, durable goods) and stress differences between border and shelf pricing. :contentReferenceoaicite:5

title: Introduction
text:
Expectations and sentiment
Household and firm inflation expectations influence near-term price dynamics and can amplify persistence. Recent surveys and syntheses highlight channels through which expectations respond to macro/news and, in turn, affect spending and pricing decisions. We will include consumer/market-based expectations as covariates in nowcasting and short-horizon prediction for selected CPI subcomponents (e.g., services), and test whether expectations improve fit beyond fundamentals. :contentReferenceoaicite:6

title: Introduction
text:
Regional and distributional perspectives
Regional price parities (RPPs) allow comparisons of price levels across U.S. states/metros, while implicit regional price deflators facilitate real-income comparisons over time. On the household side, BLS Consumer Expenditure Survey (CE) micro and tables show inflation differed across income groups (2006–2023), with lower-income households often facing higher effective inflation—informing our burden/inequality angle that combines CPI sub-indexes with expenditure weights and CE microdata. These sources support panel or distribution-aware analyses by region and demographic group. :contentReferenceoaicite:7

title: Introduction
section: How this literature shapes our models and angles
text:
How this literature shapes our models and angles

Food. Use ARDL/local projections with energy & wage drivers and category-specific lags; compare pass-through strengths pre/post COVID following ERS and Fed evidence. :contentReferenceoaicite:8

Shelter. Treat market-rent indexes as leaders for CPI shelter; estimate lag structure and persistence per Ball (2025); stress regime/break tests. :contentReferenceoaicite:9

Transportation. Test asymmetric (rocket/feather) pass-through from crude/wholesale to retail gasoline using threshold ARDL or state interactions. :contentReferenceoaicite:10

Utilities. Include HDD/CDD in STL/X-11 decompositions and ARDLs for electricity/gas CPI; evaluate energy price channels. :contentReferenceoaicite:11

Supply-chain/Policy. Implement breaks/regimes and annotate policy cycles consistent with NBER results on 2021–2022 shifts. :contentReferenceoaicite:12

Trade/Dollar. Use dollar/import price drivers selectively for traded-goods categories; distinguish border vs retail pass-through. :contentReferenceoaicite:13

Distribution/Regions. Combine CPI category paths with CE expenditure weights and RPPs to assess burden by income/region. :contentReferenceoaicite:14

title: Introduction
text:
Selected References (links)

USDA ERS — Food Price Outlook and methodology (2019–2025). :contentReferenceoaicite:15

Ball, L. (2025). Market Rents and CPI Shelter Inflation (NBER/SSRN). :contentReferenceoaicite:16

Blair, B. F., & Ruf, B. (2017). Price pass-through in U.S. gasoline markets. Energy Economics. :contentReferenceoaicite:17

Cook, S. (2019). Replicating rockets and feathers. Energy Economics. :contentReferenceoaicite:18

EIA/EPA — HDD/CDD technical docs and outlook materials. :contentReferenceoaicite:19

Bai, X., et al. (2024). The Causal Effects of Global Supply Chain Disruptions on Inflation (NBER WP 32098). :contentReferenceoaicite:20

Boz, E., Gopinath, G., & Plagborg-Møller, M. (2017). Global Trade and the Dollar (NBER/IMF). :contentReferenceoaicite:21

Coibion, O., & Gorodnichenko, Y., et al. (2020–2025). Inflation expectations and policy (surveys & synthesis). :contentReferenceoaicite:22

BEA — Regional Price Parities and methods; Real Personal Income (IRPD). :contentReferenceoaicite:23

BLS — Consumer Expenditure Survey (overview, tables, PUMD); inflation by income analysis. :contentReferenceoaicite:24

Cavallo, A., et al. (2021). Tariff Pass-Through at the Border and at the Store. AEA: Insights. :contentReferenceoaicite:25
